astamori: Astamori damage and the can only be @L[Core:Healing]{healed} with @L[Category:Martially powered abilities]{martially powered abilities} such as @L[Ability:Recover]{Recover} and @L[Ability:First Aid]{First Aid}. This includes @L[Condition:Dead]{death} and @L[Condition:Unconscious]{unconsciousness} imposed by it.
deadly: If damage is deadly, it maintains all the same @L[Category:Damage types]{damage types}, but deals exactly 50 damage and is also @L[Damage:Lethal]{lethal}. This counts as a @L[Category:Killing effects]{killing effect}.
dirtydark:
When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with dirtydark damage or dealt it while @L[Condition:Down]{down}, they are @L[Condition:Terrored]{terrored}. This condition ends when they are no longer @L[Condition:Down]{down}. Dirtydark damage also leaves lasting long term health consequences that may take years to be observed. If a creature takes dirtydark damage, roll 1d100 each month. If they took N damage, then a roll of N or lower means they develop stage 1 black rot. For every month that passes without black rot developing, the chance of getting it decreases and the number lowers by 1. But the risk of black rot it never goes away entirely. Unless properly treated, a roll of 1 will always lead to black rot, no matter how it's been since the dirtydark damage was taken. If a creature develops black rot, they start to weaken and age rapidly. For every month with black rot, roll 1d100. On a roll of 50 or less, the black rot progresses to the next stage.

Black Rot
Stage Symptoms
1 Fatigue and shortness of breath. Become permanently @L[Condition:Encumbered]{lightly encumbered}.
2 Roll 1d4 to determine if the black rot starts in the arm, leg, vitals, or body. The body part becomes permanently @L[Condition:Hacked]{hacked} and loses all color, becoming a sickly grey instead. If vitals was rolled, roll 1d4 to determine which part of the vitals was affected.
3 The black rot starts expanding to other parts of the body. Start @L[Drain:Wither]{withering} at a rate of 1 per day. And roll 1d4 each week to determine what area of the body black rot expands into. If you roll an area that already has it, progress the @L[Condition:Hacked]{hack} accordingly. This means adding an additional arm, leg, or vitals @L[Condition:Hacked]{hack}. If it progresses in the body, take 1d10 @L[Drain:Wither]{wither}. A creature with stage 3 black rot is also @L[Keyword:Inept]{inept} at @L[Category:Magically powered abilities]{magically powered abilities}.
4 The black rot progresses to all parts of the body. The creature is fully @L[Condition:Hacked]{hacked}, takes 1d10 @L[Drain:Wither]{wither} each day and is @L[Keyword:Incapable]{incapable} of @L[Category:Magically powered abilities]{magically powered abilities}. They also develop a @L[Ability:Thin Soul]{Thin Soul}.
5 If a creature survives to stage 5 black rot, they become @L[Keyword:Incapable]{incapable} of all @L[Category:Resistance effects]{resistance}, @L[Category:Hexproof effects]{hexproof}, @L[Category:Hexseal effects]{hexseal}, and @L[Category:Immunity effects]{immunity effects} and they start @L[Condition:Suffocating]{suffocating}. They also develop a @L[Ability:Frail Soul]{Frail Soul}.

Black rot cannot be removed with @L[Ability:Cure Illness]{Cure Illness} or @L[Ability:Exorcism]{Exorcism}.
financial: Financial damage is damage that occurs via wealth, but still reduces @L[Core:HP]{HP}. Financial damage counts as a @L[Category:Financial effects]{financial effect}. When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with financial damage, they are "indebted" an amount equal to the amount of damage dealt. The indebted creature is @L[Condition:Hollied]{hollied} and @L[Condition:Terrored]{terrored}. Anyone touching the indebted creature may take the @L[Ability:Pay Gold]{Pay Gold} action to pay off a portion of the debt. Once the debt is less than or equal to zero, the conditions are removed.
fire: When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with fire damage or dealt it while @L[Condition:Down]{down}, they are @L[Condition:Burned]{burned}. This condition ends when they are no longer @L[Condition:Down]{down}.
hack:
Hack damage does not reduce @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}. Instead, it applies different @L[Category:Conditions]{conditions} or effects to creatures depending on the part of their body being hacked. Hack damage will always have some body part specified.

Arm Hacks
1st Arm Hack: @L[Category:Attack abilities]{Attacks} you make with handheld @L[Category:Item delivery abilities]{items}, @L[Category:Missile delivery abilities]{missiles}, or your @L[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hands} are done with @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}. And you cannot make any @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} requiring two hands (such as those with @L[Property:Two-Handed]{two-handed} @L[Category:Weapons]{weapons}). You also cannot execute @L[Category:Somatic component abilities]{somatic abilities} unless both your hands are free.
2nd Arm Hack: You now cannot @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}, @L[Category:Block abilities]{block}, nor use any other @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} with handheld @L[Category:Item delivery abilities]{items}, @L[Category:Missile delivery abilities]{missiles}, or your @L[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hands} at all. You also cannot execute @L[Category:Somatic component abilities]{somatic abilities} at all.
Leg Hacks
1st Leg Hack: You are @L[Condition:Slowed]{slowed} and @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} you make with your @L[Equipment:Foot]{feet} are done with @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}.
2nd Leg Hack: You are @L[Condition:Immobilized]{immobilized} and cannot make @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} with your @L[Equipment:Foot]{feet}.
Vitals Hacks
The effects of Vitals Hacks have even more granularity. Vitals Hacks will always have a more specific body part specified and apply effects accordingly.
Vitals Ear Hack: You are @L[Condition:Deaf]{deaf}.
Vitals Eye Hack: You are @L[Condition:Blind]{blind}.
Vitals Nose Hack: You are @L[Condition:Anosmatic]{anosmatic}.
Vitals Mouth Hack: You are @L[Condition:Mute]{mute} and cannot make @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} with your @L[Category:Equipment]{mouth}.
Body Hacks
You are @L[Condition:Immobile]{immobile}.

Despite not reducing @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}, hack damage can be @L[Core:Healing]{healed}. @L[Core:Healing]{Healing} hack damage does not typically consume @L[Core:Hit Dice]{hit dice}. However, one @L[Core:Hit Dice]{hit die} worth of @L[Core:Healing]{healing} only mends one Hack. Each type of Vitals Hack must be @L[Core:Healing]{healed} independently. Arms and legs must receive an amount of @L[Core:Healing]{healing} equal to the amount of Hacks they've taken in order to be fully @L[Core:Healing]{healed}.
holy: When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with holy damage or dealt it while @L[Condition:Down]{down}, they are @L[Condition:Hollied]{hollied}. This condition ends when they are no longer @L[Condition:Down]{down}.
ice: When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with ice damage or dealt it while @L[Condition:Down]{down}, they are @L[Condition:Frozen]{frozen}. At the end of each of your actions, they roll 2d4. If either of these dice roll a 4, this effect ends.
lethal: When a creature is reduced to 0 @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or below due to lethal damage, it is instead reduced to half their maximum @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} below zero @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}. If this is not possible, their @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} reduces to the lowest value it can go to. This counts as a @L[Category:Killing effects]{killing effect}.
magic: Magic damage has no innate properties. However, it can affect creatures that only take @L[Ability:Magical Durability]{only take magic damage} such as @L[Category:Greater undead creatures]{greater undead}.
morganti: Morganti damage cannot be @L[Core:Healing]{healed}. This includes @L[Condition:Hacked]{hacks}, @L[Condition:Dead]{death} and @L[Condition:Unconscious]{unconsciousness} imposed by it. If a creature is @L[Condition:Dead]{killed} with morganti damage then they cannot be @L[Category:Revival effects]{revived}.
mundane: Mundane @L[Core:Damage]{damage} is @L[Core:Damage]{damage} that is not explicitly @L[Damage:Magic]{magic}. It could be any other @L[Category:Damage types]{damage type}.
psychic: Psychic damage is damage that occurs via the mind, but still reduces @L[Core:HP]{HP}. Psychic damage counts as a @L[Category:Mental effects]{mental effect}. When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with psychic damage, they take 1d10 @L[Drain:Mana]{mana drain} as well.
silveel: Silveel damage can @L[Core:Damage]{damage} any creature that could be @L[Core:Damage]{damaged} by @L[Damage:Silver]{silver damage} or @L[Damage:Magic]{magical damage}. It is also @L[Keyword:Boosted]{boosted} against @L[Category:Undead creatures]{undead creatures}.
silver: Silver damage has no innate properties. However, it can affect creatures with @L[Ability:Impure Durability]{Impure Durability} such as @L[Category:Full undead creatures]{full undead}.
spiritual: Spiritual damage is damage that occurs via the spirit, but still reduces @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}. Spiritual damage counts as a @L[Category:Spiritual effects]{Spiritual effect}. When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with Spiritual damage, they are @L[Keyword:Vulnerable]{vulnerable} to the creature that @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} them until dawn.
starbright:
Starbright damage is a rare @L[Category:Damage types]{damage type} dealt by @L[Property:Starbright]{starbright} items. It acts as any other @L[Category:Damage types]{damage type} or combination of @L[Category:Damage types]{damage types} for the purposes of being able to deal damage to creatures, but has none of those @L[Category:Damage types]{damage types} other effects. For instance, if a creature is somehow @L[Keyword:Immunity]{immune} to all @L[Core:Damage]{damage} other than @L[Damage:Fire]{fire}, starbright will @L[Core:Damage]{damage} them as though it was @L[Damage:Fire]{fire} but will not @L[Condition:Burned]{burn} them. If a different creature had only @L[Ability:Fire Damage Immunity]{Fire Damage Immunity}, then starbright would @L[Core:Damage]{damage} them as though it was something other than @L[Damage:Fire]{fire} @L[Core:Damage]{damage}. So long as there exists some @L[Category:Damage types]{damage type} that can @L[Core:Damage]{damage} a creature, then starbright will work against them. If a creature is somehow @L[Keyword:Immunity]{immune} to all @L[Core:Damage]{damage} then starbright will not affect them.

A consequence of starbright's versatility is that it is also immutable. It always deals exactly 1d8 starbright @L[Core:Damage]{damage}, cannot be @L[Keyword:Boosted]{boosted} or @L[Keyword:Deboosted]{deboosted}, cannot have its @L[Core:Damage]{damage} amount changed such as with @L[Ability:Tumble]{Tumble}, and it cuts through @L[Category:Resistance effects]{resistances} but is not considered to be @L[Keyword:Warded]{warded}. It cannot be converted to @L[Category:Drain types]{drain} or some other effect such as through @L[Ability:Chi Strike]{Chi Strike} or @L[Ability:Withering Damage]{Withering Damage} and supersedes all other @L[Category:Damage types]{damage types} that might be dealt with the same die as it. For instance, using @L[Ability:Slay]{Slay} with a @L[Property:Starbright]{starbright} @L[Category:Equipment]{dagger} will still deal only 1d8 starbright @L[Core:Damage]{damage}. However, using the same dagger with @L[Ability:Control and Resist Fire]{Control and Resist Fire} will deal 1d8 starbright + 1d4 @L[Damage:Fire]{fire} @L[Core:Damage]{damage} because the @L[Core:Abilities]{ability} adds a different @L[Core:Damage]{damage} die. If that @L[Core:Damage]{damage} is then @L[Keyword:Boosted]{boosted} it will deal 1d8 starbright + 2d4 @L[Damage:Fire]{fire} @L[Core:Damage]{damage}, completely ignoring the starbright @L[Core:Damage]{damage} die.

@L[Category:Attack abilities]{Attacks} that deal starbright @L[Core:Damage]{damage} can still be stopped physically such as through @L[Core:Block Interaction]{blocking} or by @L[Category:Armor]{armor}.
terror: When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with terror damage or dealt it while @L[Condition:Down]{down}, they are @L[Condition:Terrored]{terrored}. This condition ends when they are no longer @L[Condition:Down]{down}.
toxic: Toxic damage is damage that occurs within a creature's body, but still reduces @L[Core:HP]{HP}. Toxic damage counts as a @L[Category:Poison effects]{poison effect}.
vine: When a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{dropped} with vine damage or dealt it while @L[Condition:Down]{down}, they are @L[Condition:Snared]{snared}. This condition ends when they are no longer @L[Condition:Down]{down}.
